newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy 97 mini-budget enough for EMU-Veltroni.
newsitem.headline: Italy 97 mini-budget enough for EMU-Veltroni.

text.p: Italy's 1997 mini-budget should be sufficient to ensure the country meets the deficit target of three percent of Gross Domestic Product required for membership of Europe's single currency, deputy prime minister Walter Veltroni was quoted as saying on Friday.

Veltroni, quoted by the ANSA news agency, was responding to reports from a European Union source and in Italian newspapers that European Commission officials were forecasting an Italian deficit-to-GDP ratio of 3.2 percent for this year.

"Our commitment from the moment we began working has been to achieve the three percent of deficit to GDP and thus enter Europe. We think the mini-budget is sufficient to meet that objective," Veltroni was quoted as saying.
He declined specific comment on the 3.2 percent assessment, which an EU source in Brussels said could change before the Commission releases its spring forecasts next Wednesday.
"We are going to wait to read these assessments when they are published," Veltroni said.

Italy's centre-left government has drawn up a 15.5 trillion lire supplementary budget for this year to try to ensure the country makes the grade for first wave membership of Europe's planned economic and monetary union (EMU) in January 1999.
